Knowledge Graph Driven Business Text Processing Tutorial

15th December Thursday from 9:00 am to 1:00 pm

ICON 2022 Conference

ABOUT THE TUTORIAL

As organizational decision making becomes more and more data-driven, Business Intelligence (BI), that had traditionally focused on analyzing attributed numerical data, is now rapidly bringing in unstructured data into its fold. Though Information Extraction (IE) from text documents is quite a mature area of Natural Language Processing, organizing, aggregating and querying the extracted information is still not an easy task. Knowledge graphs play an important role to bridge the gap.

A knowledge-graph captures real-world knowledge in the form of a network of real-world entities and their rela- tions, assimilated from a multitude of sources. It contains nodes which represent the entities, edges which represent the inter-entity relationships and labels, that capture the semantics or meaning of the relationships. Existing knowledge graphs like YAGO, DbPedia, Freebase etc. capture knowl- edge about significant world entities like business organizations, business concepts, intra and inter-organizational relationships, people knowledge etc. which can be fused with information obtained from business texts to enable contextual interpretation. Domain specific ontologies like The Gene Ontol- ogy for Genomics, Financial Industry Business On- tology (FIBO) ontology for the financial industry, the Geopolitical Ontology built by Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) have extensive use in processing natural language content in the respective domains.

Focus of the tutorial

  • Use of Knowledge graphs to organize information extracted from textual sources
    • How knowledge-graphs aided information extraction methods can help in extracting, organizing, combining and storing information from unstructured sources with data from other business applications for efficient retrieval
  • Knowledge graphs for information retrieval
    • The work that has advanced the area of business information extraction using natural language expressions. We will be covering methodologies that are adopted to convert unstructured queries expressed in natural language to graph queries and/or mathematical/algebraic expressions for execution over underlying structured knowledge graphs.

Expected background and prerequisite of audience

  • Familiarity with NLP and DL models like BERT
  • Familiar with problem statements of Entity and relation extraction
